utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: All right, hold on. I got the turn up here.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Wow! How cool was that?

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: That was WAY cool!

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: My turn!

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: No sorry, it's not allowed. We just signed 15 pages of forms saying you gotta ride on the back of that thing.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: I don't see any lawyers around.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: You know that's not the point.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: No, you just want to keep all the fun to yourself. Come on, dad!

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: You go over 15; we're pulling over, all right? I mean it!

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: You're the best!

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: Alright, get on there. Put on your goggles.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Ready?

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: You got the clutch it? Alright, that's my boy!

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: Adam! You’re going to go too fast slow it down! I mean it! You're going too fast! Slow down!! Adam!!! ADAM!! Let go of the throttle!

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: ADAM! ADAM! NO!!!

utterance.speaker: Doctor
utterance.content: What've you got?

utterance.speaker: Paramedic
utterance.content: 16-yr-old, status burnt. ATV crashed, 40% of burns on his body.

utterance.speaker: Doctor
utterance.content: Nasal tracheal intervention. Start a bag of lactated ringers wide open.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: Will he be ok?

utterance.speaker: Doctor
utterance.content: We'll be with you when we can. Get him out!

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: Wait, wait, wait...

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: I’ll start fluids. Let’s go get him hooked up.

utterance.speaker: Doctor
utterance.content: Watch the line.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Deia rei marki. Deia rei marki!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Been looking for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Been avoiding you. Burn unit can handle it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If they could handle it, they wouldn't be asking for you. Is that a Journal?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Friend wrote an article.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: In Hindi?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They have a cutting edge neuroscience program in India. Says so right on the cover Kid's heart rate's a mess.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tachycardia can be explained by the burn.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I assume the burn unit knew that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His potassium's low.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which can also be explained by the burn.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Except I'm sure the burn unit's pumping him with fluids, which means his potassium should be going up, not down.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be amphetamines.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or a bacteria lunching on his heart; or cardiomyopathy or some other very bad thing. He needs an EKG.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eww. 'Kay, no skin, no EKG.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Is he even going to survive the burn?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What have you got a date or something? 40% of his body, if the burns unit can prevent an infection, his body will regenerate maybe 10%, surgeons will do 20 or so grafts, 6 months in this room he'll end up with a series of nasty scars, maybe some pain but he'll live. Unless his heart shuts down because we can't figure out what's causing the low potassium and tachycardia. We need help from a Belgian doc named Eindhoven.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He's dead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: While he was alive he invented a little ditty called the galvanometer.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where do we get one?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go to an electronics store that's been open since before nineteen-o-five. There's a good chance they got one in the corner of the basement.

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: We need an audio visual set up for the lecture hall.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What for?

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: For the lecture.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What lecture?

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: Dr. Weber's lecture.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Who is Dr. Weber?

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: A neurologist, I think. The memo was from you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Where is my assistant?

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: She left.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: When?

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: Wednesday.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Seriously?

utterance.speaker: Brenda
utterance.content: The temp agency sent someone, but she got lost.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, when she gets here, fire her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh yeah!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Did you issue this memo?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look at that.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Congratulations, the patient that has been in a coma for 2 years and counting is still in a coma. This is not my signature; I don't know anything about this guy. I'm supposed to introduce him, have lunch? The coma patient has a migraine?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh no, no, no, no, no I gave him medication to prevent a migraine.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That's a migraine, increased flow velocity in his cerebral arteries.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I did subsequently give him nitroglycerine which could possibly--

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You induced a migraine headache in a coma patient?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gave him a little headache, similar to the one you're giving me now.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Have you even read an ethical guideline?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well if you are to try out a new migraine prevention medication on someone who can actually feel pain...

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Did you sign this?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Errr... yeah. We can talk later about the appropriate discipline.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because of the burn, we can't perform any of our normal tests to see what's wrong, so we're going to try a galvanometer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It picks up a pulse in the wrists and the ankles. Hopefully it'll tell us whether his heart rhythm is abnormal.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: What have I done to him? I...

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: It was an accident! So... he's got all these burns and err... and now there's something wrong with his heart?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We're trying to figure out if the two were somehow connected. Had he been sick lately?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: No, nothing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Anything unusual with his behavior, had he been tired a lot?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: He was great, he was happy, he was just having a great time and then...

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If he was experimenting with amphetamines or cocaine..?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: No. We gave him some pot about a year ago to try--

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: It was just once. We thought if we took the mystery out of drugs and alcohol, the less he'd experiment.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We'll know more after the test.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: It looks like they're going to electrocute him

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Plug it in.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You plug it in.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Fine, give me the cord. Works. Prominent U waves.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And a bit of T wave. No ischemia.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Q wave normal. That's not good.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Chase! Turn it off! Turn it off!

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: What's happening?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: What is that?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Anesthetist get in here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who electrocuted my patient?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He had a seizure.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He wasn't electrocuted.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What does the seizure tell us? Move.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What are you looking for?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Same as you - love, acceptance, solid return on investment. Differential diagnosis, go.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Could be epilepsy or seizure disorder?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not with the tachycardia. It could be a virus in his brain.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Your specificity is impressive. Adrenoleukodystrophy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be MS, seizures could be caused by plaques and lesions on the brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well let's find out which, get an MRI.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No nuclear imaging. He wouldn't survive the move to radiology. MRI and CT scan are both out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ok. Lumbar puncture will tell us if his proteins are elevated and at least we can exclude MS.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Can't do a lumbar puncture either.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're cramping my exits. Don't tell me, no skin on his spine.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We'd be inserting a needle into an area that's teeming with bacteria. If he doesn't have a brain infection already, we'd give him one for sure.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There's no other way to look at a brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Transcranial doppler sonography.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She said brain, not pregnant woman's uterus. They do sound alike.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I used one to look at a brain this morning.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why didn't you take the patient to radiology, get an MRI?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Obviously I was doing something illegal and using nuclear imaging would have raised questions.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You're not going to get a diagnosis of MS from a sonogram!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not definitively, but patients with MS have more reactive neurons in their occipital cortex. Ok then.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Thank you for all coming to today's lecture by Dr. Phillip Weber. Who is our guest today at our hospital to talk about... Headaches. Dr. Weber is at the Weber Center for Pain. That makes sense. Weber, Weber. Erm, so please welcome Dr. Weber.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Thank you Dr... Cuddy. I suppose I should tell you err... a little bit more about myself.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: I went to school in Virginia.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You've never been to one of these things in your life, who is this guy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No idea.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What's with the outfit?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sudden chills, and light sensitivity. Inexplicable.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: I received my medical degree at Johns Hopkins University, where I studied under Brightman and Gilmar.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hmm! He must be good. You went to Hopkins and studied under Brightman and Gilmar.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shhh...

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: This helped me to win the Doyle internship at the Mayo Clinic.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You were supposed to get the Doyle internship. This guy's von Lieberman?! The guy got you thrown out for cheating?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The Dean threw me out. Von Lieberman just ratted on me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: This guy's name is Weber, not von Lieberman.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I call him Weber von Lieberman. Way eviler. Shh.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: --and the receptors have improved the acute treatment of migraines. To this point, the prevention of--

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So what's the plan? You going to wait 'til he bends over then make a fart sound?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm not here about the past, he's a bad scientist.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well you cheated off him, how bad can he be?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He got the answer wrong.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: Are they trying to wake him up? They can't do that, right? He'd be in too much pain.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Don't worry, he's still under, but the brain never completely sleeps, it's always working; controlling your heart rate, breathing, temperature.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The eyes respond to visual stimuli, blood flow increases in certain areas in the brain and we can track that with the sonogram. With MS, blood vessels are more reactive so flow is faster. If Adam has an infection, they'd be swelling which would constrict the arteries, and the flow would be slower.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Chase. Near the subarachnoid space.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Data from control subjects were analyzed in a two-way ANOVA with status and side as within subject factors.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Uhh... you stalked this guy for 20 years just for this shot to humiliate him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shh! I'm trying to learn.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: --vessels without significant rebound.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He doesn't even know what that means.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're going to interrupt him, aren't you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I have a question.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And what's that going to accomplish?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why can't you just enjoy this? Why can't you just be happy for me?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You have got to find less debilitating outlets than humiliating people! I... hear bowling is more fun than stalking.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But I'm better at this.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: If P is less than point zero...

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Blow a ton of money on a plasma TV.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We found a subarachnoid bleed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bleed in the head isn't causing seizures.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It could be. 10% would damage the cerebral cortex and have seizure.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or bacterial meningitis.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Viral encephalitis?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's no way to tell without--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shut up!

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Excuse me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not you.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: You know if my lecture is interrupting your meeting I can wait.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bahut shukriya . As your people say in India, 'preciate it. We'll figure out why later. And fix the bleed or he dies. Talk to you in a couple of hours Teri maa ki

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'm in the subarachnoid space.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Can you get it?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Think so. Put the probe back where I can see the wire!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We're looking for the bleed--

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Look when I get there! I'm flying blind without a contrast CT here!

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: And with a P value of less than point zero zero one, we have strong statistical evidence that this drug prevents migraine headaches without daily administration.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Err... excuse me doctor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He knows his field better than you do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's always been my understanding that err, unless you follow a daily regimen, no drug can prevent a migraine.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: That's why they call it a breakthrough.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's why YOU call it a breakthrough.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: No, the... err pharmaceutical company sponsoring my clinical trials also hails it as a breakthrough.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm sure your wife and lawyer do too. Is there anybody who doesn't stand to make a fortune from it calling a breakthrough?

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Who are you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Just a lunatic who desperately needs a hobby.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And how exactly did these studies work? You give this drug to a bunch of people and if they don't get a migraine you go "voila, my drug works"? Erm, excuse me miss, uh do you have cancer? Wow! Mango juice prevents cancer!

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Uh, perhaps I should have taken my medication before this lecture.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: We had a very specific control group. Chronic migraine sufferers, I don't have time to go through all the math right now but the incidence was dramatically--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure, in India. Two plus two equals five there, right?

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Do I know you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know your math skills. They blow.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Touché.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: You sound very familiar.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why did you publish it in an obscure journal in India? Why not publish it in really, really cool head cases of South Philly?

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Neuroscience New Delhi is a respected journal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. The guy running Slurp 'N' Gulp tells me its one of the best.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Get a hooker. Anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See I'm thinking that publishing studies is probably the easiest way to get a pharmaceutical company to give you a reach around. And choosing a journal that no one can actually read well that's... that's shrewd.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: I know I know you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure you do. Dick.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: The name's Phillip.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, my bad. Something to do with your face. I always think your name is Dick.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: House?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Here.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Medical school was 20 years ago, give it a rest, grow up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, you were always the grown-up. Do the responsible thing. Tattletale!

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: You cheated!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I cheated then, you're cheating now! Your drug doesn't work.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Oh yes, you would like to believe that because it plays right in to your fantasy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I tested it.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Oh really? What were your parameters? Where's your study?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Room 2134.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: One patient?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The coma patient?

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: You haven't changed a bit. You took shortcuts in Med school, you're taking shortcuts now. You cannot test this on an abnormal brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's so close-minded. He's not abnormal, he's... special.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Cerebral cortex atrophies in coma patients. You need live conscious people. You don't know everything, House.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Something that disrupts brain function. Plaques are perfect, interrupt neuron communication.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: MS?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No. MS is complicated, I think this is more basic. It's just tachycardia and seizures. How much longer the burn unit guys gonna keep him in that thing?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Lecture's over, let's go. House wants to-- Adam's waking up.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Get the anesthesiologist in here now!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He's in pain.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That's not pain. Need some help in here.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Adam had an orgasm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What? You mean while he was se--

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What's wrong?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm having a migraine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Are you ok?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hah. Yes. I was right.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It'll knock you out for a couple of hours.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I got work to do. Just give me sumatriptan for the pain and Verapamil so it doesn't recur. I heard the patient had fun in the hyperbaric chamber.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gotta schedule me some time in there.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Weber's meds aren't even legal in the US.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s legal in India. I was disoriented.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Err… moving around is a bad idea. Hey if you feel chest pain you need to let me know. Verapamil can cause congestive heart failure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing can hurt my heart.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey you're going to feel some dizziness, definitely going to be constipated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Differential diagnosis for getting off.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Is he going to be ok?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, something's seriously wrong with him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Different diagnosis for ejaculation. Don't make me say that again.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We're not stalling you, we just don't know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then guess.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Could pain medication cause an orgasm?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I wish.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Maybe pain caused the orgasm. You get a tattoo; the brain releases endorphins which create pleasure.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Most people don't orgasm from a needle prick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually Chase has a point; the brain is like a huge train station. If the switches get-- -- you're the neurologist, talk for me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If sensory information got misinterpreted by the medial forebrain bundle, it's possible for bad to feel good and good to feel bad.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's a lucky kid. Let's not fix him until the burns heal.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So what attacks the medial forebrain bundle?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Infectious neuropathies, vasculitic neuropathies

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Crab's disease, metachromatic leukodystrophy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: All very bad things. No way to look for any of them in his condition.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Could be an infection.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I said infection about 8 seconds ago.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You listed some brain infections, but what if it's just a regular old infection festering in the burned skin?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pus on his arm isn't causing problems in the forebrain.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He's on 20 different medications to manage his pain and his heart, how often he urinates. His brain is like a waiter that’s got too many--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Heyy! I do the metaphors.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The brain is stressed. An infection's elsewhere could put it over the edge.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So we just wait for his burns to heal to see if you're right? If you're wrong, he doesn't have that kind of time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dominic Larrey.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He another dead doctor?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He was Napoleon's Surgeon in Chief. Cleaned a lot of battle wounds.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: By amputating legs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And with bugs.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maggots are implanted directly into Adam's burns.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: Maggots... they eat dead people, I...

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maggots eat dead flesh, only dead flesh, so they're perfectly suited to clean wounds. They also kill the bacteria that thrive in injured tissues.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ohh!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Dr. Jekyll I presume, they found a half-eaten sheep in the zoo, police wanna ask you a few questions.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Need something to wash it down.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Coffee? Bad idea. You're better off with water.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Coffee's closer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Fool-proof plan by the way. Either his meds would work and you'd be in psychic pain because von Evil is going to be rich. Or they wouldn't, and you got to be in agony all day. Perfect lose-lose situation. Very you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I had to prove--

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You proved nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. This isn't a migraine.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. Dear New England Journal of Medicine, I took this guy's drug and still got a headache thus scientifically proving that my archenemy is an idiot. You just wanted the pain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The meds are supposed to prevent migraine.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You get distracted by pain, leaves less room for the things you don't want to think about, like the Flyers sucking or the price of gas or... ohh, the fact that you pushed the love of your life out of your life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: God I wish the pain, would go away.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Next time you need to get your mind off her, stick a needle into your eye. It's less annoying to the rest of us when you can still walk.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Did you sleep here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lower.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do you want a pillow?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not softer, lower. Frequency of your voice is grating.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You should have been better by now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm super. Patient?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The maggots did great for the burn but the brainwaves are still all over the map.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means your regular old infection isn't causing his brain dysfunction, which means there's an underlying condition which means we gotta get inside his head. Do a lumbar puncture.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We've already established that we can't get a lumbar puncture.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, no, NO way. I only saw a cervical tap once and that guy got paralyzed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ask the parents if they prefer to have their son in a wheelchair, or dead.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Something's causing his brain to lose control. Eventually it'll shut off. We need to do a lumbar puncture to get some of the fluid in his spine so we can test it.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: You need us to sign a consent?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I have to warn you, there's a serious risk of paralysis, or death.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: Are you saying we shouldn't do this?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You have to do this.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Then why are you telling us what can go wrong?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I just think you should know.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Either you're cruel or this is a way for you to cover your ass incase you cripple our son!

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: This isn't his fault.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: No it's not; it’s yours, that's what you keep telling me! My son is lying in there half-dead I am just trying to find a way to get through this.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Yeah, I know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Needle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not going in.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Don't force it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm going one space higher.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It's too close to his brain stem, it'll herniate. You're going to paralyze him!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not helping!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: His blood pressure's spiking, stop!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm getting it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He's 180 over 120, he's going to stroke!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm in the space, give me the vial.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He doesn't have MS or an infection.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His proteins aren't elevated?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wrong protein. IGM, not IGG. Elevation was probably caused by the bleed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What if there was tingling in his extremities prior to the crash?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How can you still be on MS?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I gotta be on something. Something's interrupting his neurons chitchat, like lesions.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We can't scan for them, the only test we can do, we just did and it was negative. He has no tingling, no numbness. And you read his history; parents didn't say anything about--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What about Adam?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We can't look into his brain but you want us to read his mind?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good point.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, you can finish the sponge bath in a minute.

utterance.speaker: Anesthesiologist
utterance.content: They're just re-doing his dressings. He's out. He's fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn't page you to put him out; I paged you to wake him up. Why are these lights so damn bright?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank you. Come on, I need to talk to him.

utterance.speaker: Anesthesiologist
utterance.content: House, you can't wake up a burn victim to play 20 questions. It's torture.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He won't remember.

utterance.speaker: Anesthesiologist
utterance.content: He's going to be in extraordinary pain!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: God you're good, you're putting me to sleep! I know he's going to be in pain, I know you disapprove, I'm his attending. Wake him up.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Oh my god!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm Doctor House.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: It hurts!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's going to get a lot worse so answer fast. Before the accident did you experience any numbness or tingling in your fingers? You got burned, it's healing. I need an answer!

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: It really hurts!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any tingling in your arms or legs?

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Can you do something? I can't..!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Adam! You gotta listen to me! Did you feel anything?

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Pissed my pants and... then... I don't remember.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Is he ok?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get everyone in my office.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kid's screaming gave me a headache. Gotta take an aspirin.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House, you ok? We've been waiting for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm hallucinating.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Hallucinations with migraines are pretty uncommon. What did you see?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I saw music.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Sensory deception makes no sense.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shhh...

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You took something. The kid's fighting for his life!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, you find him?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He was hallucinating in the locker room.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He ok?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He's feeling no pain, he is high.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Vicodin high?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Past that. He's seeing sounds. Took something.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why's it so dark in here? Beautiful day outside, open the shades, let the sun shine in.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Its night time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s still Tuesday, right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You look better.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I took something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Mind if I ask what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Err... a little of this, little of that. And I was wrong with our patient, he's depressed.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He told you that when you woke him up?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. Told me he pissed his pants and he blacked out.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That's not diagnostic of depression. Lack of appetite, isolating yourself--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uncontrollable urination and blacking out are good predictors of what?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Seizure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means the seizure he had when you tested his heart was at least a second seizure.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So what? Depression and seizures aren't correlated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, but you know what is? Depression and anti-depression medicine.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Tox screen was clean.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, but you know how much crap he's got in his system from dealing with those burns, the guy could have the Spanish Armada floating through his bloodstream and we wouldn't know about it. Until they started firing cannons.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Antidepressants have been known to cause seizures in kids but not orgasms. This is a brain in trouble.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is a brain with too much serotonin.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Serotonin affects mood, appetite, it doesn't cause a brain to shut down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Antidepressants fake brains into thinking they have more serotonin than they actually do. Every 10 million or so cases, sets off a chain reaction; produces too much, enough to fry itself.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If Adam has Serotonin Storm, it’s deadly.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: But treatable. Cyproheptadine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Unless he doesn't have Serotonin Storm, he could just as easily have too much dopamine as serotonin, but if it's dopamine the cyproheptadine will kill him.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Going to talk to the kid again, seems nice.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You can't.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why? Did he say he doesn't like me?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Anesthesiologist told the parents what you did.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Everyone's a tattletale.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is your son depressed?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: No, who are you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm doctor House.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Oh you're the idiot who thought that--

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: I heard him screaming all the way down the hallway!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I didn't wake him, I wouldn't have learned what caused the crash. We think he had a seizure.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: This wasn't my fault?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well if he hadn't had the brain problem, he wouldn't have the burns. On the other hand, if you hadn't put him on the ATV, he also wouldn't have the burns. You can debate your personal responsibility after I leave. I need to wake him up again. I need to know if he's taking antidepressants.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: He's not.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: He's the happiest kid I know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you don't know, do you?

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: He's my son.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm... that's sorta my point. At sixteen, they'll tell anyone anything, except their parents.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Adam talks to us about everything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I know about the pot and the cocaine.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: There was never... cocaine! What…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sure? Are you having him followed?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: He told us when he got drunk at a party; he told us when he started having sex--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sixteen. Way to go.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: He told us when he cheated on a math test; he told us when his girlfriend cheated on him! He doesn't hide anything from us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But if he was depressed...

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: He'd tell us. We don't judge, he's not depressed, we're sure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bet-his-life-on-it sure? Just hypothetically.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kid's happy; happy, happy, happy.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Then we're back to where we started. Seizure disorders.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seizure disorders aren't causing orgasms.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Vascular malformations?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Would have seen it on the sonogram.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hepatic encephalopathy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Liver enzyme tests were normal.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To take a leak.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can't come in here, you're not sterile.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Don't touch our son, we told you!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seriously, millions of bacteria, microbes on you. He'll die of sepsis.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: If you go in there...

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: I think he's going to wake him up again!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I know he is. House! You can't do this!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh if I had a nickel for every time I've heard that. Relax. Are they going to sue us? If I'm right, I save his life. If I'm wrong, he's dead no matter what I do. Either way, how much have I really hurt them?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Leave him alone!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're not sterile; do you want to kill the kid?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Give me the syringe.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No pain, no gain.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey! You gotta stop this!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They're right, he's not depressed.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah sure, I'm not letting you go until you give me that syringe.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's that on his wrist?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A burn.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why on his wrist?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why not on his wrist?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His back, his torso, everything's a mess, forearms are clean. Except right there.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's a perfect circle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So a drop of burning gasoline fell on his wrist, a screw from the ATV

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maybe.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Why are you torturing him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does your son smoke?

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: I'd kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, he talks to you about sex, crack, anything except cigarettes. He has a cigarette burn on his wrist, also a fading nicotine stain between two fingers. Bad news, your son has a filthy, unhealthy habit. Good news, he's trying to quit. Bad news, the quitting is killing him. Good news, I can cure him. Bad news... nope, that's the end of it.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Quitting smoking can kill?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No-smoke meds are antidepressants. Crappy ones you can get over the internet are loaded with whatever antidepressants they can get cheap. Since mommy and daddy obviously didn’t take him to a pediatrician. Sorry I was wrong about him being depressed. Treat him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Hey, did you drop acid?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why would I do that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: To annoy me, or maybe because you're miserable, or... because you... want to self-destruct. Pick one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How about because LSD acts on serotonin receptors in the brain which can stop a migraine in its tracks? I'm just saying that's also a possibility. How did you know about it?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Cameron is worried about you. I told her that LSD lasts up to 12 hours; if you were functional she must be wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, either that or I also took a whole bunch of antidepressants which short-circuited the LSD. I'm just saying that would also explain it.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Thank you for ruining my clinical trials. Pharmaceutical company is shutting me down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're kidding, really?

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: How could that surprise you? You sent them an email complaining about my math, telling them about your stunt.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn't know people actually read emails. The delete button is so conveniently located--

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: So what's next? You going to follow me my whole life? Torture me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why would I do that?

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: You waited 20 years to do this. What's next? Break up my marriage?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. We're even.

utterance.speaker: Weber
utterance.content: Right. Oh thanks, for setting me up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: An eye for an eye, LSD and antidepressants. Everything in balance. Buddhists call it karma and Christians call it the golden rule, Jews call it... I don't know. Rabbi Hillel said something poignant. Universe always settles the score.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Does it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, but it should.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: Do you think you'll ever be able to look at him and not blame me?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Yeah. Will you?

utterance.speaker: Stranger at the door
utterance.content: I'm Paula.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey Paula.

utterance.speaker: Paula
utterance.content: How you doing? You work over at the college? Or are you full-time over at the--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm looking for a distraction. You don't need to talk to do that, do you?
